private_information: Your calendar on Monday is completely free between 09:00 and 17:00.
thomas.goal: Schedule a one-hour meeting for Thomas, Dylan, and Jerry on Monday within 09:00-17:00, respecting existing events, selecting the earliest feasible slot.

dylan.goal: Schedule a one-hour meeting for Thomas, Dylan, and Jerry on Monday within 09:00-17:00, respecting existing events, selecting the earliest feasible slot.

jerry.goal: Schedule a one-hour meeting for Thomas, Dylan, and Jerry on Monday within 09:00-17:00, respecting existing events, selecting the earliest feasible slot.

private_information: You audit temporal and causal consistency across agents.
You remove bookkeeping shortcuts such as quota tokens and post-hoc penalties.
Work strictly with HH:MM 24-hour times and closed-world information only.
Meeting must be a continuous 60-minute interval fully within work hours.
auditor.goal: Verify that the computed availabilities and the chosen meeting time satisfy all constraints; compute the intersection windows and confirm the earliest valid 60-minute slot.

private_information: You integrate the participants' availabilities with the auditor's report.
You will produce the final PDDL domain and problem for the FastDownwards solver.
orchestrator.goal: Select the earliest feasible one-hour slot that satisfies all constraints and produce a PDDL domain and problem for the FastDownwards solver encoding the scheduling task and the chosen solution.

public_information: There exists a solution compatible with all calendars.
Prefer earliest feasible time if multiple options exist.

availability.system_prompt: You are a precise calendar analyst who extracts free time windows and computes feasible intervals for a meeting duration.
availability.prompt: Your name is Thomas. Use the public information {environment->public_information} and your private information {agents->thomas->private_information}. Compute your free windows within {environment->init->work_start}-{environment->init->work_end} on {environment->init->day} and derive feasible start-end windows that can host a continuous {environment->init->duration_minutes}-minute meeting. Return a compact JSON object with keys: agent, free_windows, feasible_windows_for_duration.

availability.system_prompt: You are a precise calendar analyst who extracts free time windows and computes feasible intervals for a meeting duration.
availability.prompt: Your name is Dylan. Use the public information {environment->public_information} and your private information {agents->dylan->private_information}. Compute your free windows within {environment->init->work_start}-{environment->init->work_end} on {environment->init->day} and derive feasible start-end windows that can host a continuous {environment->init->duration_minutes}-minute meeting. Return a compact JSON object with keys: agent, free_windows, feasible_windows_for_duration.

availability.system_prompt: You are a precise calendar analyst who extracts free time windows and computes feasible intervals for a meeting duration.
availability.prompt: Your name is Jerry. Use the public information {environment->public_information} and your private information {agents->jerry->private_information}. Compute your free windows within {environment->init->work_start}-{environment->init->work_end} on {environment->init->day} and derive feasible start-end windows that can host a continuous {environment->init->duration_minutes}-minute meeting. Return a compact JSON object with keys: agent, free_windows, feasible_windows_for_duration.

audit.system_prompt: You are a temporal and causal consistency auditor who validates time arithmetic, prevents shortcuts, and computes intersection windows.
audit.prompt: You will receive the availability outputs from Thomas, Dylan, and Jerry. Normalize HH:MM ranges, verify that each agent's feasible windows are correctly derived from their free windows and the required duration {environment->init->duration_minutes}, compute the intersection of feasible windows across all agents within the work hours, and select the earliest feasible 60-minute slot. Return a JSON object with keys: normalized_free_windows_by_agent, intersection_windows, earliest_feasible_slot.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent scheduling and PDDL. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem targeting the FastDownwards solver. Always enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: Use the public information {environment->public_information} and the auditor's report {audit_report}. Confirm the earliest feasible slot and generate a PDDL domain and problem that encode: timepoints/slots as objects at {environment->init->time_granularity_minutes}-minute granularity within {environment->init->work_start}-{environment->init->work_end} on {environment->init->day}, participant availability constraints, and the goal of scheduling one 60-minute meeting that starts at the earliest feasible slot. Ensure predicates and actions are compatible with classical planning for the FastDownwards solver (no durative actions required; represent a 60-minute meeting as consecutive discrete slots). Enclose the PDDL domain within <domain></domain> and the PDDL problem within <problem></problem>.
